text:
(1)
Liberty Square, at the intersection of Fulton, Liberty and Tillary Streets. At the right, is the Fulton Elevated Lines of the B.M.T. on Fulton Street. At the left, is the Myrtle Ave., Elevated Lines of The B.M.T. on Tillary Street. At the right, is seen Clinton Street at Fulton Street; Also the Hotel Touraine on Clinton Street. The other tall buildings are to the south in the Borough Hall section.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from another angle. The view at the right foreground, beyond the building with the "Brown Paint Co." sign was the site of the "Second Presbyterian Church" from 1831 to 1882 when it consolidated with the "Clinton Street Presbyterian Church" located at the S.E. corner of Clinton and Remsen Streets and became known as the Spencer Memorial Church (Presbyterian).

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Liberty Square, at the intersection of Fulton, Liberty and Tillary Streets. At the right, is the Fulton Elevated Lines of the B.M.T. on Fulton Street. At the left, is the Myrtle Ave., Elevated Lines of The B.M.T. on Tillary Street. At the right, is seen Clinton Street at Fulton Street; Also the Hotel Touraine on Clinton Street. The other tall buildings are to the south in the Borough Hall section.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from another angle. The view at the right foreground, beyond the building with the "Brown Paint Co." sign was the site of the "Second Presbyterian Church" from 1831 to 1882 when it consolidated with the "Clinton Street Presbyterian Church" located at the S.E. corner of Clinton and Remsen Streets and became known as the Spencer Memorial Church (Presbyterian).

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Remsen Street, west from Clinton Street. In the left foreground is the Hamilton Club, organized on November 2, 1830 as the Young Men's Literary Association; changing its name in October 1831 to the Hamilton Literary Association of Brooklyn. Henry C. Murphy became its first president. Ninety of these members founded the present club which was incorporated in May 1882. The first quarters of the organization were in the Hamilton Building, at the N.W. corner of Court and Joralemon Streets, now the Temple Bar Building. In 1884 its present site was purchased at a cost of $49,000. The Clubhouse cost another $51,000, The statue of Alexander Hamilton was erected in 1892. Also partially seen are the Church of the Pilgrims and
the Hotel Bossert.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Clinton Street, east side, from Remsen to Livingston Streets. (Joralemon Street, is in the center of the view). In the left background, is
St. Ann's P.E. Church.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1) Remsen Street, at the S.E. corner of Clinton Street, showing the Spencer Memorial Presbyterian Church.

February 22, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same; from another angle, showing also the Hamilton Club, at the S.W. corner of Remsen and Clinton Streets.

September 9, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, a further view of Clinton Street.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

May 1925.

Remsen Street, north side, west from Clinton Street. In center at right, is a view of the Church of the Pilgrims.
August 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1),
Remsen Street, north side, west from Clinton and beyond Henry Streets. Congregational Church of the Pilgrim's is seen in the center.
April 7, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same; from a more distant point nearer to Clinton Street.
March 1, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

180 Remsen Street, south side, between Clinton and Court Streets, showing the Brooklyn Union Gas Co., Building.

April 7, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Clinton Street, west side, at and south of Remsen Street, showing the demolition of building, at the S.W. corner.

December 15, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
